title: 115_hr1326
content: The Act is titled the "Department of Defense Overhead Cost Savings and Transparency Act" and requires the submission of a report. The Act titled "Department of Defense Overhead Cost Savings and Transparency Act" mandates the Secretary of Defense to submit the covered study conducted by the Defense Business Board to the congressional defense committees within 30 days of the Act's enactment. The study, titled "Transforming Department of Defense's Core Business Processes for Revolutionary Change," must also be made publicly available. Additionally, there is a provision for expedited consideration of legislation to implement the study. Qualifying legislation is defined as a bill introduced by specific members of Congress with the title "To implement cost savings in the Department of Defense as identified by the Defense Business Board" and includes provisions for short titles and findings. The qualifying legislation introduced in Congress must implement at least 80 percent of cost savings identified by the Defense Business Board in a study submitted to Congress. Legislation introduced in the House of Representatives is referred to the Committee on Armed Services of the House, while Senate legislation is referred to the Committee on Armed Services of the Senate. The Committee on Armed Services of the Senate handles Senate legislation. If the committee does not report qualifying legislation within 10 session days, it will be discharged, and the legislation will be placed on the House calendar. After the committee reports or is discharged, any Member can bring up the legislation for consideration. The motion to proceed to the consideration of qualifying legislation is privileged in the House of Representatives and the Senate, not debatable, and not subject to amendment or postponement. The motion to proceed to the consideration of qualifying legislation is privileged in the House of Representatives and the Senate, not debatable, and not subject to amendment, postponement, or reconsideration. If agreed to, the respective House shall immediately proceed to consider the legislation without interruption, and debate on the legislation is limited to 20 hours divided between the Majority Leader and Minority Leader or their designees. The motion to further limit debate on qualifying legislation is in order and not debatable. Only amendments ensuring the legislation meets specific criteria are allowed. Postponement, consideration of other business, or recommitting the legislation is not permitted. A vote on final passage will occur after debate and a quorum call if requested. The ruling of the chair on procedure for qualifying legislation is final without debate. If one House receives qualifying legislation from the other House, it cannot be referred to a committee and can only be considered for final passage. Upon receiving qualifying legislation from the other House, the procedure in the receiving House remains the same, but the final passage vote is on the legislation from the other House. Once the received legislation is disposed of, it cannot be considered in the receiving House. This section is enacted by Congress as an exercise of the rulemaking power of the Senate. The section is enacted by Congress as an exercise of the rulemaking power of the Senate and the House of Representatives, applicable only to the procedure for qualifying legislation. It recognizes the constitutional right of each House to change its rules regarding procedure.
